text: today on x cast political tensions grip
Egypt amid increasing conflict between
countries new president Mohamed Morsi
and the military on Sunday Egypt's new
president Mohamed Morsi surprised
everybody when he ordered the Parliament
that had been dissolved back into
session he said that he was trying to
restore legitimacy to the state because
the Parliament had been elected by the
people on Monday the highest court in
the land the supreme Constitutional
Court told the president that the
Parliament cannot be reseated because
the court had already ruled that it was
elected illegally so what we have is a
battle between the president and the
court where both sides are trying to
appear as though they're operating under
the rule of law but it really appears
that it's a more subtle an ongoing
battle over the future of who has
executive legislative and judicial
authority the generals who really are
controlling the situation right now have
stayed largely silent what they're
trying to do is make this appear as
though it is a battle over rule of law
and it appears that the folks who are in
opposition to the Muslim Brotherhood
that would be the court and the military
are now trying to outmaneuver them by
saying they're operating within the rule
of law whereas the president is trying
for a power grab to seat an illegal
assembly
for the time being both sides have
decided that they will try to talk the
members of parliament who have the cold
vac have not gone to the building which
is still surrounded by riot police
ostensibly to prevent them from going in
if they are seated on Tuesday it's not
even clear that all the members will
show up or what if any legitimacy they
will have because again the court has
said they were elected illegally and
President Obama fights back against weak
economic reports by changing the subject
to tax fairness Monday morning he called
for a one-year extension of the Bush tax
cuts for people earning less than two
hundred and fifty thousand dollars our
biggest challenge right now isn't just
to reclaim all the jobs that we lost to
the recession it's to reclaim the
security that so many middle-class
Americans have lost over the past decade
President Obama's announcement this
morning has kicked off a battle royal on
Capitol Hill Republicans didn't even
wait for the president to speak before
issuing their own rebuttals they argue
that this amounts to a tax increase
particularly on small business owners
and they say that the president hasn't
offered any roadmap for what would
happen a year from now even if these
cuts were extended the president's also
in some hot water with Democratic
leaders former Speaker Nancy Pelosi and
Senator Charles Schumer favor extending
the tax cuts but would do so for
everyone earning under a million dollars
that's a difference that will have to be
squared between the Democratic
leadership and the White House the
president may also have muddied his
message a bit by campaigning so
aggressively in recent months for the
Buffett Rule that's the rule that would
impose a marginal tax rate of thirty
percent on anyone earning a million
dollars or more it's named for the
investor Warren Buffett the problem with
that is it has put the idea of a million
dollars in people's minds as the
threshold between middle and very high
income earning people and to that extent
it's made the argument that the
president has a little bit more
difficult to make
you
